units.text: Learning Objectives

By the end of this module, election judges will be able to understand and prevent physical, human (insider), and cyber threats. This will be done through review of election day responsibilities, with a primary focus on areas of weakness of and/or potential threat to the electronic pollbooks.
Reference: Anne Arundel County Board of Elections election judge Manual 2020 Presidential Election (pp. 10.2-10.58).
Summary:

The security of U.S elections has always been of high concern. However, with threats to our elections becoming more frequent, we need to ensure our elections are safe from attack. Because voting operations judges using the electronic pollbooks at the check-in table are typically the first to interact with voters, you are our first line of defense. This module will prepare you to provide the utmost security while in the role of working the electronic pollbooks at the check-in table.

We have identified areas of weak security that can be improved with election judge assistance. This module will take you through these areas of weaknesses and provide you with mitigations to improve security.
Together, we can secure the privacy of our elections.
Unpacking the Electronic Pollbook

items: Ensure the Inner Tamper Tape Seal is intact and not voided. If voided, inform the Chief Judge. Do not remove this seal!
Take off the outer security seal and place all broken security seals in the red Tamper Tape & Security Seals Bag.
Open the two latches.
Take the electronic pollbook and power cord from the case. Handle the electronic pollbook with care by removing the pollbook by the elastic band.
Verify the State Asset Tag & Tamper Tape Seal numbers match, check off/sign your initials in the check column. Bipartisan judges must also sign initials in the column.
Make sure the inner seal number on top of each electronic pollbook is not broken and the number matches the numbers in column 3 on the Electronic Pollbook Integrity Report.
Verify the power switch on the top is turned OFF.
Insert the power cord (marked with yellow tape) into the first connection slot marked with PWR.  Plug the other end into a power source.  Do NOT turn on the power switch yet.
Take the printer’s USB cable from the printer case.  Plug the larger end into one of the two USB ports located on the back of the electronic pollbook.  It does not matter which USB port you use.
Plug one end of the printer’s power cord (marked with blue tape) into the printer. Plug the other end into a power source.
Plug the smaller end of the USB cable into the printer.
Repeat all steps for each electronic pollbook.

• Ensure the electronic pollbook power cord, USB cable from the printer, and USB cable to the router is connected securely and correctly.
  • When connecting the electronic pollbook and router to power via its power cord, be sure to use a power strip with a surge supressor to prevent shortages and electrical damage to the electronic pollbook.
  • Be sure to plug the devices in outlets that are out of the reach of voters and heavy foot traffic.
  • Be sure to keep all cords out of voter’s path and reach. All cords on the floor should be taped down to avoid becoming a tripping hazard.

units.text: Checking the Electronic Pollbook

items: Turn the power switch to ON.  Do not network the electronic pollbooks yet.
When the electronic pollbook switch is ON, the Launch screen will appear. If the date or time is incorrect, tell a chief judge right away.

Make sure the poll name on the left side of the screen is correct. Then tap the OK This is Correct Poll button at the bottom of the screen. If the polling place is not correct, tell a chief judge right away.
Select Yes or No when you are asked to check that the time in the bottom right corner matches the correct time
Change the date and time as necessary using the instruction on page 10.9 of the 2020 Election Judge Manual
The Main Screen will appear with the Manage Polls tab at the top of the screen. The poll status will be Closed.

Tap the Ballots and Voters tabs under the Statistics to make sure that all the numbers are zero. Be sure to check both tabs under Statistics for zeros before networking the electronic pollbooks. Tell a chief judge right away if any of the numbers are not zero
Make sure that the totals at the bottom of the screen are zero
Repeat all steps for all electronic pollbooks

• Be sure to introduce yourself to all other election judges. Establish lines of communication in case problems arise
  • Follow the instructions beginning on page 10.12 of the 2020 Election Judge Manual to properly open the electronic pollbooks:
    • Check synchronization by ALWAYS ensuring the electronic pollbooks are synchronized. If problems arise, alert a chief judge who will seek technical assistance.
    • Throughout the day, periodically check the vote totals at the bottom of the screen against the other electronic pollbooks in the polling place. All totals should match, but some pollbooks may take a few seconds to match with the other pollbooks.
  • When prompted to sign in, be sure use your first name and/or initials.
  • Remember: DO NOT check-in voters before 7:00 AM.

units.text: Finding Voters in the Electronic Pollbook

items: When checking in voters, election judges may not ask for ID but may accept it if offered by a voter.
Regardless of presented ID, election judges must ALWAYS ask the voter to state their name, address, and month and day of birth.
If the name, address and month & date of birth match exactly, print out the Voter Authorization Card. Have the voter verify the information is correct by signing the appropriate line.
If their information is not correct, follow-up with the appropriate actions. When in doubt, ask for help from fellow election judges or one of the chief judges.

NEVER leave your pollbook unattended. When helping a voter for an extended period of time, SIGN OUT of your pollbook.
  • This will help prevent any unauthorized users from accessing and/or tampering with the pollbook.
  • Review “Resetting the Judges Name” beginning on page 10.49 of the 2020 Election Judge Manual.

If you have ANY issues with a voter, especially in “Special Situations,” DO NOT hesitate to ask a chief judge for assistance.
  • Refrain from asking occupied election judges for assistance.

units.text: Closing the Polls

items: Ensure the electronic pollbook and all related materials are returned to their cases.

units.text: Equipment Management Assessment

units.prompt: You are currently checking-in a voter. You have asked the three required questions and used their name to look up the voter in the electronic pollbook. While asking the three required questions, the voter gives you an address that does not match what is on the electronic pollbook. What are you NOT to do?

choices.text: Continue to issue regular ballot.
Ask voter if they have moved within the last three weeks.
Ask a fellow election judge or chief Judge for assistance.

units.prompt: It is about 9:00 AM and you decide to check the electronic pollbook synchronization. You notice that your electronic pollbook says DEM 34 and your neighbors electronic pollbook says DEM 32. What should you do?

choices.text: Notify the Chief Judge immediately.
Wait about 30 seconds to see if the electronic pollbooks count matches up. If it does not match up within a minute, notify the chief judge.
Disconnect the electronic pollbooks from the router for 10 seconds, then reconnect.
Disconnect the router from its power source, wait 10 seconds, then reconnect to power.

units.prompt: When unpacking an electronic pollbook, how do you verify that the electronic pollbook belongs at your polling location?

choices.text: Ensure the outer and inner seal number of the electronic pollbook matches the number on the Electronic Pollbook Integrity Report for each respective electronic pollbook.
Ask the Chief Judge to check each electronic pollbook.
Verify the outer seals on the electronic pollbooks have not been broken.
If they come out of the black carrying case, then those are the correct electronic pollbooks for that polling location.
Out-of-state driver’s license.
An expired photo ID card.
Any non-photo ID that is more than 3 months old.
A membership card (Sam’s Club, gym, etc.).
A Voter Notification Card.
A Social Security Card.
Any non-photo ID with an address that does NOT match the Electronic Pollbook or the new address on the Voter Update Form.
None of the above.

units.prompt: Where do we place all Outer Seals that have been cut?

choices.text: Red Tamper Tape and Security Seals Bag.
Red 'Contents to be Posted. Folder.
Chief Judges’ Blue Official Results Binder.
None of the above.

units.prompt: Outer seal numbers and asset tag numbers from each pollbook are recorded on which form?

choices.text: Ballot Marking Device Integrity Report.
Scanning Unit Opening Integrity Report.
Electronic Pollbook Integrity Report.
Chief Judge Election Day Log.
None of the above.

units.text: In this section, we will work to reduce the chances of a cyber threat within our polling locations.
As a voting operations judge working in the check-in area, you can reduce the chance of unauthorized equipment/data tampering through remote access using electronic devices in the polling location.
You can reduce cyber threats by:

items:
NOT using your cell phone or any other electronic device while at the polling location. Cell phone/technology usage is PROHIBITED for voters and election judges in the polling place.
  • Use of any technology poses a silent but dangerous cyber threat to our elections and must be removed IMMEDIATELY.
Being aware of suspicious and/or adverse behavior and actions.
Watching over other election judges, observers, voters, and election material.
Providing assistance ONLY when you are available.

Notifying the chief judge of ANY AND ALL suspicious or adverse behavior or actions from fellow election judges, observers, voters, etc.
  • Individuals posing as election judges may attempt to tamper with election equipment/processes.

units.text: Cyber Threat Assessment

units.prompt: You notice a fellow election judge texting under the table with their cell phone. What should you do?

choices.text: Politely ask them to put their phone away.
Remind them that voter nor election judges are permitted to use their cell phones in the polling location.
Politely ask the election judge to step outside of the polling place to use their cell phone.
Any of the above.

units.prompt: While scanning the polling location, you notice the election judge at the scanning unit is sleeping in their chair. What should you do?

choices.text: Leave your station to wake the sleeping election judge.
Notify a chief judge
Throw a piece of paper at the sleeping election judge.
Scream at the sleeping election judge.

units.prompt: As a voting operations judge working in the check-in area, how can you determine if your electronic pollbook may have been tampered with during voting hours?

choices.text: The tamper tape on the electronic pollbook itself shows signs of meddling.
You did not sign out of your electronic pollbook before leaving your station.
Your electronic pollbook does not successfully synchronize with other electronic pollbooks in a reasonable amount of time.
All of the above.

units.text: This section will aid you in identifying and mitigating the impact of insider threats at your polling location.

The most obvious insider threats involve election judges compromising the election process by posing as an election judge and deliberately tampering with election devices, thus corrupting the process; observers distracting election officials; and individuals posing as observers actually being malicious actors. Election judges, voters and observers can tamper with the equipment.

You can reduce and prevent insider threat by being vigilant and aware during polling place set-up, while preparing the electronic pollbook on election morning, throughout the day when registering voters, and while assisting in closing the polling location.
If any situation arises when an observer must become involved, never leave your equipment unattended and immediately contact the chief judge.
Insider Threat Assessment

units.prompt: You are checking in a voter when an observer comes to you and questions the voter's identity, giving their probable cause. What are you to do?

choices.text: Get up and retrieve the chief judge.
Stop what you are doing and call upon the chief judge.
Explain why this person can vote at the designated precinct.
Ask the election judge beside you for help to prove the voter can vote at the designated precinct.

units.prompt: You witness a person wearing a grey jacket, repeatedly re-enter then leave the entrance of the polling location. What should you do about your suspicions?

choices.text: Nothing. This is a free country and the person can do as they please.
Talk about it with other election judges.
Promptly notify the chief judge of your suspicions.
Leave your station to ask the suspicious person to stop their distracting activities.

units.prompt: How do you protect the information stored in the electronic pollbook when you leave your station during voting hours?

choices.text: Flip the electronic pollbook on its screen so no one can press buttons or touch the screen.
Have the chief judge or another election judge watch your electronic pollbook while you step out.
Unplug or disconnect the electronic pollbook from its power source until you return to your station.
Sign out of your assigned electronic pollbook each time you leave your station flip the electronic poll book on its screen.

units.text: In this final section, you will learn how to reduce/prevent physical threats to our elections at your designated polling location.
Some physical threats that our elections are susceptible to include memory stick(s) being compromised, individuals stealing passwords, and resetting polling machine settings prior to the election.
Election Morning

items:
Ensure the electronic pollbooks show NO evidence of tampering.
  • Check tamper tape.

units.text: During Election Day

items:
Be aware and watch over other persons in the polling location. Provide assistance only when available.
  • NEVER to leave your electronic pollbook unattended. When helping a voter for an extended period of time, SIGN OUT of your pollbook.
Watch and assist other election judges when able to ensure all steps are being done correctly.

Notify the chief judge of ANY AND ALL suspicious or adverse behavior or actions from fellow election judges, observers, voters, etc. Individuals posing as election judges may attempt to tamper with election equipment/processes.

units.text: Closing the Polls

items: When closing the polling location, make sure that the inner tamper tape seal on the top of each electronic pollbook has not been broken.
Check the tamper tape and compact flash card on the electronic poll book for tampering.

Pack the electronic pollbooks in their cases and seal each case with a closing outer booth security seal provided by a chief judge and be sure the outer booth security seal is recorded on the Electronic Pollbook Integrity Report.

units.text: Physical Threat Assessment

units.prompt: It has been three hours since the polls opened and you need to use the restroom. What should you do?

choices.text: Look to see if there are any incoming voters; if not, run to the restroom.
Tell your fellow election judges you will be using the restroom and then leave.
Notify your fellow election judges and a chief judge. When voter traffic slows down, sign out of your electronic pollbook and quickly use the restroom.

units.prompt: The outer booth security seal placed on each pollbook when the polls are closed should be recorded on which form?

choices.text: Ballot Marking Device Integrity Report.
Scanning Unit Opening Integrity Report.
Electronic Pollbook Integrity Report.
Chief Judge Election Day Log.
None of the above.

You may check off this step on the card. To move on to the next step, click on the following link: http://tinyurl.com/PollbooksQuiz.
